justification: "Fixation duration and search rate have been commonly used as metrics to characterise visual search behaviour (Harris et al., 2021; Janelle, 2002; Williams et al., 1994)."

The same passage notes that "search rate" together with fixation duration "have been commonly used as metrics to characterise visual search behaviour," linking this construct to the search-rate metric.
"Entropy can therefore index whether a performer is performing a structured and systematic scanning pattern, or a highly variable and random one… we adopted … Gaze Transition Entropy."

After defining persistent vs. antipersistent saccades, the authors state, "In the present context more persistent saccades would indicate a more structured and efficient search," so the proportion of antipersistent saccades indexes search structure.

"Time to fixate first target… represented the duration… from entering the room to when the participant's gaze vector first intersected with a target" and was used "to assess whether participants were locating threats… more quickly."
"A proxy measure for correct search order was used… This measure was calculated as the proportion of total trials in which this criteria was met (%)."
Performance metric defined as "number of instances where shots landed on non-threatening targets," indexing failures of inhibitory control.
"Time to shoot all hostiles – the time from entering the room until all hostile targets had been shot, as calculated by the VR software (in seconds)."

The authors define "Missed hostiles – whether there were any threatening targets left in the room that were not successfully shot… (as a proportion of all hostile targets)," thereby measuring accuracy in eliminating threats.
